pr_title: Add PathSpecSet: a set of PathSpecSet with support for full projection

timeline.message:
Add PathSpecSet: a set of PathSpecSet with support for full projection

The PathSpecSet provides functionalities to more easily build or edit a set of PathSpec. In addition, it offers the support for a full projection so that methods like "contains" always return true making it easier for the client code to write logic with the set.

timeline.bodyText:
I'm skeptical about using the terminology "full projection", as PathSpecs are not inherently tied to Rest.li projections (that's just one application). However, one could make the argument that the term "projection" is a generic term and isn't implying that it's used for Rest.li projections. What do you think?
I'm also curious to know how a "full projection" PathSpecSet is used. Do you have an example of one use case?
timeline.author: evanw555

replies.bodyText: maybe we can change to name "universal". Otherwise the "full" return a empty set and NULL in toArray seems unnatural to me as well
replies.author: junchuanwang
GuiForget

replies.bodyText: For the toArray() returning null, this is consistent with the behavior of the method fields(PathSpec[]) in the Rest.li builders.
replies.author: GuiForget

replies.bodyText:
I'm used to full projection so it is difficult for me to come up with an alternative. I'm not sure universal as an adjective works but I could see universe or universeSet as suitable. Here are some alternatives that I found in a thesaurus dictionary:

globalSet
allInclusiveSet
blanketSet
replies.author: GuiForget

replies.bodyText:
When no projection is specified, the ProjectionMask is null and you want to make sure that contains(PathSpec) returns true for any PathSpec and that's the meaning of a fullProjection.

In this specific use case it makes sense, but this object is simply a set of path specs. An empty path spec set articulates to a full projection when it's used in the specific application of projection, but path specs aren't only for projections. What does an empty path spec set mean when it's being used for indexing values from a complex data object, or matching ReadOnly/CreateOnly predicates? I don't necessarily think that an empty path spec set contains everything for all use cases.
replies.author: evanw555

replies.bodyText: thanks for the explanation, I will vote for "allInclusiveSet".
replies.author: junchuanwang

replies.bodyText:
Synced up with @GuiForget about this offline. He clarified that an empty set is not necessarily the same as an "all inclusive" or "full projection" set, which must be created explicitly as such.
As for naming, I say we avoid using the terminology "full projection", and instead use something that implies inclusivity. allInclusive/isAllInclusive works for me. complete may also be good, but I'm not sure if that has a different technical definition when it comes to sets.
replies.author: evanw555

replies.bodyText: I renamed fullProjection to allInclusive and propagated the changes throughout the classes and unit tests
replies.author: GuiForget
